Award.AwardTitle: Analytical Method to Assess Dynamic Response of Tall Buildings to Downburst Windstorm

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vertical structures such as tall buildings and horizontal-axis wind turbines are prone to wind-induced vibrations and potential damage originating from complex wind-structure interaction. The relevance of this issue has attracted engineering researchers in recent years because of the tendency to erect taller buildings and larger-diameter-blade wind turbines in the United States and other parts of the World. The design of tall structures is usually based on steady and stationary wind load conditions. However, winds are often transient, such as in the case of a downburst storm, a meteorological phenomenon which induces an outburst of damaging wind loads near the ground. The study of transient wind loads is also relevant since increasing number of structures is damaged by this type of events. This project pursues to develop a viable computational method for the dynamic response assessment of tall structures against a downburst type of storm.

This project will pursue a novel analytical method for assessing the stochastic dynamic response of tall structures due to transient wind loads. The method will account for system nonlinearity and aerodynamic coupling effects. The method will be based on the concepts of compactly supported wavelets and the Wavelet-Galerkin transform, which enables reducing a system of differential equations to an algebraic form by preserving time-frequency features in the modeling. The study will advance the utilization of Wavelet-Galerkin method for solving wind-induced coupled nonlinear stochastic dynamic problems. Moreover, the project will investigate the dynamics, caused by transient downburst-like winds, on a series of reduced-order models of tall structures. Examples will include two benchmark tall buildings and one large-diameter horizontal-axis wind turbine. The research will validate the analytical method by conducting wind tunnel experiments on scaled models of the benchmark buildings. Integrated outreach activities are planned to disseminate the findings of the study through educational tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has tackled the emerging problem of accurate and computationally efficient stochastic dynamic response analysis for tall buildings subjected to loads from thunderstorm downburst windstorms. These non-stationary wind systems are downdrafts of air that impinge on the ground and subsequently generate intense radial outflows. The resulting localized, transient, highly complex, and rapidly-varying wind fields render traditional wind engineering analytical techniques, typically employed for larger, synoptic systems such as hurricanes, inadequate. Utilizing such conventional frequency-domain methods that assume stationary properties of wind velocity measurements (i.e. wind speed does not change rapidly in magnitude and direction over time) may yield inaccurate, underestimated structural loads and responses, overpredicting the performance capabilities of afflicted tall buildings. Throughout the course of this project, this issue was addressed by the novel application of the Wavelet-Galerkin method which uses discrete wavelets (locally, supported compact waves), rather than infinitely long harmonic waves used in frequency domain analysis, to approximate the response of a tall building structure impacted by nonstationary wind loading.

 The objectives of the project have been achieved by implementing the Wavelet-Galerkin method for the investigation of the coupled dynamics of various vertical, slender structures. Fundamental analysis and comprehensive derivation of the equations that govern the motion of these structures are conducted using a numerical simulation procedure that captures the primary atypical characteristics of downburst wind storms (e.g. slowly-varying mean wind speeds, evolution and passage of the thunderstorm, rapidly-varying wind field fluctuations) and fluid-structure interactions. The Wavelet-Galerkin method was subsequently applied to approximately solve these equations, yielding the consequent dynamic vibration of the slender structures under the simulated simplified non-stationary wind loads. The numerical method has further advanced other investigative studies. The relevance of unsteady vortex-shedding effects and induced loading was examined for the generic tall building during a short thunderstorm downburst landfall. In addition, the computational efficiency of the Wavelet-Galerkin method, in comparison with equivalent time-domain simulation techniques, led to the extension of stochastic analyses into the preliminary performance-based investigation of tall buildings subjected to non-stationary loading from thunderstorm downbursts. A preliminary application of the wavelet-based method for tornadoes has also been performed, showing promising results in approximately replicating tornado-induced structural dynamic vibrations.

 Physical verification of the numerically simulated loads was conducted using a multi-blade flow device in a small-scale boundary-layer wind tunnel to generate a rapidly-varying gusty flow. The flow experimentally simulated a non-stationary gust front and its loads on a tall building model at a geometric scale 1:750.

A major outreach accomplishment of the project was the organization of BBAA VIII, 8th International Colloquium on Bluff Body Aerodynamics and Applications, a conference where the Principal Investigator and those in the research community shared their findings related to not only thunderstorm downburst winds and tornadoes but also other areas in wind engineering. Using information derived from the project, awareness against thunderstorm hazards was also presented to graduate students in a wind engineering graduate course, offered at Northeastern University. Other product outcomes stemming from the project include several archival journal publications, one peer-reviewed book chapter and several conference publications.

The project enabled the simulation of dynamics of tall buildings subjected to non-stationary wind loading and further emphasized the importance of downburst windstorms in structural analysis. The numerical results have demonstrated that such non-stationary wind fields are capable of inducing large-amplitude tall building responses, comparable to those from other wind phenomena such as synoptic winds and hurricanes, which are mainly contemplated in current design standards.

 The impact from this study will promote the investigation of non-stationary wind loads on structural systems with regards to structural dynamic vibration analysis, accommodating for the growing demand for structures less vulnerable to damages and loads from thunderstorm downbursts (and other nonstationary wind phenomena). The application of the proposed method is one step towards achieving this objective, further promoting the use of various stochastic dynamic approaches in structural engineering.
